title: Overview
content:
{{Short description|Mammalian protein found in Homo sapiens}} {{cs1 config|name-list-style=vanc|display-authors=6}} {{distinguish|Aniline}} {{Redir|Anillin|similar words|Aniline (disambiguation)}}{{Infobox_gene}}

'''Anillin''' is a conserved protein implicated in cytoskeletal dynamics during cellularization and [[cytokinesis]]. The ''ANLN'' [[gene]] in humans and the scraps gene in ''Drosophila'' encode Anillin.<ref name = "Piekny_2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Piekny AJ, Maddox AS | title = The myriad roles of Anillin during cytokinesis | journal = Seminars in Cell & Developmental Biology | volume = 21 | issue = 9 | pages = 881–91 | date = December 2010 | pmid = 20732437 | doi = 10.1016/j.semcdb.2010.08.002 | url = https://spectrum.library.concordia.ca/7014/1/PieknyandMaddox2010.pdf }}</ref> In 1989, anillin was first isolated in embryos of ''[[Drosophila melanogaster]]''. It was identified as an F-actin binding protein.<ref name = "Zhang_2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Zhang L, Maddox AS | title = Anillin | journal = Current Biology | volume = 20 | issue = 4 | pages = R135-6 | date = February 2010 | pmid = 20178751 | doi = 10.1016/j.cub.2009.12.017 | doi-access = free | bibcode = 2010CBio...20.R135Z }}</ref> Six years later, the anillin gene was cloned from cDNA originating from a Drosophila ovary. Staining with anti-anillin (Antigen 8) [[antibody]] showed the anillin localizes to the nucleus during interphase and to the contractile ring during cytokinesis.<ref name = "Field_1995">{{cite journal | vauthors = Field CM, Alberts BM | title = Anillin, a contractile ring protein that cycles from the nucleus to the cell cortex | journal = The Journal of Cell Biology | volume = 131 | issue = 1 | pages = 165–78 | date = October 1995 | pmid = 7559773 | pmc = 2120607 | doi = 10.1083/jcb.131.1.165 | doi-access = free }}</ref> These observations agree with further research that found anillin in high concentrations near the cleavage furrow coinciding with RhoA, a key regulator of contractile ring formation.<ref name= "Piekny_2008">{{cite journal | vauthors = Piekny AJ, Glotzer M | title = Anillin is a scaffold protein that links RhoA, actin, and myosin during cytokinesis | journal = Current Biology | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | pages = 30–6 | date = January 2008 | pmid = 18158243 | doi = 10.1016/j.cub.2007.11.068 | s2cid = 6310134 | doi-access = free | bibcode = 2008CBio...18...30P }}</ref>

The name of the protein anillin originates from a Spanish word, ''anillo''. ''Anillo'' means ring and shows that the name anillin references the observed enrichment of anillins at the contractile ring during cytokinesis. Anillins are also enriched at other actomyosin rings, most significantly, those at the leading edge of the Drosophila embryo during cellularization. These actomyosin rings invaginate to separate all nuclei for one another in the syncytial blastoderm.<ref name = "Piekny_2010" />

title: Structure
content:
Anillin has a unique multi-domain structure. At the N-terminus, there is an actin- and myosin-binding domain. At the C-terminus, there is a [[PH domain]]. The PH domain is conserved and essential for anillin functionality.<ref name = "Piekny_2008" /> The human anillin cDNA, located on Chr7, encodes a 1,125–amino acid protein with a predicted molecular mass of 124 kD and a pI of 8.1. The mouse anillin gene is located on Chromosome 9.<ref name = "Oegema_2000">{{cite journal | vauthors = Oegema K, Savoian MS, Mitchison TJ, Field CM | title = Functional analysis of a human homologue of the Drosophila actin binding protein anillin suggests a role in cytokinesis | journal = The Journal of Cell Biology | volume = 150 | issue = 3 | pages = 539–52 | date = August 2000 | pmid = 10931866 | pmc = 2175195 | doi = 10.1083/jcb.150.3.539 | doi-access = free }}</ref>

There are also numerous anillin-like protein homologues found outside of metazoans. In ''[[Schizosaccharomyces pombe]]'' (fission yeast), there are Mid1p and Mid2p. These two anillin-like proteins do not have any overlap in their functions. Mid1p has been characterized as a key regulator in cytokinesis, responsible for arranging [[contractile ring]] assembly and positioning.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Saha S, Pollard TD | title = Characterization of structural and functional domains of the anillin-related protein Mid1p that contribute to cytokinesis in fission yeast | journal = Molecular Biology of the Cell | volume = 23 | issue = 20 | pages = 3993–4007 | date = October 2012 | pmid = 22918954 | pmc = 3469515 | doi = 10.1091/mbc.E12-07-0536 | doi-access = free }}</ref> Mid2p acts later in cytokinesis to organize [[septins]] during septation, or the invagination of inner membranes, outer membranes, and the cell wall that occurs in order to separate daughter cells completely.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Tasto JJ, Morrell JL, Gould KL | title = An anillin homologue, Mid2p, acts during fission yeast cytokinesis to organize the septin ring and promote cell separation | journal = The Journal of Cell Biology | volume = 160 | issue = 7 | pages = 1093–103 | date = March 2003 | pmid = 12668659 | pmc = 2172762 | doi = 10.1083/jcb.200211126 | doi-access = free }}</ref> ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'' (budding yeast) also have two anillin-like proteins, Boi1p and Boi2p. Boi1p and Boi2p localize to the nucleus and contractile ring at the bud neck, respectively. They are essential for cell growth and bud formation.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Toya M, Iino Y, Yamamoto M | title = Fission yeast Pob1p, which is homologous to budding yeast Boi proteins and exhibits subcellular localization close to actin patches, is essential for cell elongation and separation | journal = Molecular Biology of the Cell | volume = 10 | issue = 8 | pages = 2745–57 | date = August 1999 | pmid = 10436025 | pmc = 25510 | doi = 10.1091/mbc.10.8.2745 }}</ref>

[[File:Anillin.jpg|thumbnail|The domains found in anillin across species]]

title: Function
content:
Anillins are required for the faithfulness of cytokinesis and its F-actin-, myosin-, and septin-binding domains implicate anillin in actomyosin cytoskeletal organization. In agreement with this belief, anillin-mutant cells have disrupted contractile rings. Additionally, it is hypothesized that anillin couples the actomyosin cytoskeleton to microtubules by binding MgcRacGAP/CYK-4/RacGAP50C.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = D'Avino PP, Takeda T, Capalbo L, Zhang W, Lilley KS, Laue ED, Glover DM | title = Interaction between Anillin and RacGAP50C connects the actomyosin contractile ring with spindle microtubules at the cell division site | journal = Journal of Cell Science | volume = 121 | issue = Pt 8 | pages = 1151–8 | date = April 2008 | pmid = 18349071 | doi = 10.1242/jcs.026716 | doi-access = free }}</ref>

Anillins have also been shown to organize the actomyosin cytoskeleton into syncytial structures observed in Drosophila embryos or C. elegans gonads. ANI-1 and ANI-2 (proteins homologous to anillin) are essential for embryonic viability in both organisms. ANI-1 is required for cortical ruffling, pseudocleavage, and all contractile events that occur in embryos prior to mitosis. ANI-1 is also crucial for segregation of polar bodies during meiosis. ANI-2 functions in the maintenance of the structure of the central core of the cytoplasm, the [[rachis]], during oogenesis. ANI-2 ensures oocytes do not disconnect prematurely from the rachis, thereby leading to the generation of embryos of varying sizes.<ref name = "Maddox_2005">{{cite journal | vauthors = Maddox AS, Habermann B, Desai A, Oegema K | title = Distinct roles for two C. elegans anillins in the gonad and early embryo | journal = Development | volume = 132 | issue = 12 | pages = 2837–48 | date = June 2005 | pmid = 15930113 | doi = 10.1242/dev.01828 | doi-access = free }}</ref>

In vitro experiments suggest that anillin drives myosin-independent actin contractility.<ref name="kucera2021">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kučera O, Siahaan V, Janda D, Dijkstra SH, Pilátová E, Zatecka E, Diez S, Braun M, Lansky Z |date=2021| title=Anillin propels myosin-independent constriction of actin rings | journal=Nature Communications| volume=12|issue=1| pages=4595| doi=10.1038/s41467-021-24474-1|pmid=34321459| pmc=8319318|bibcode=2021NatCo..12.4595K}}</ref>

title: Binding Partners
content:
===Actin=== Anillin specifically binds F-actin, rather than G-actin. Binding of F-actin by anillin only occurs during [[cell division]]. Anillin also bundles actin filaments together and drives their relative sliding.<ref name="kucera2021" /> This contractile behavior is independent of myosin and ATP and may couple with actin filament disassembly. Amino acids 258-340 are sufficient and necessary for F-actin binding in Drosophila, but amino acids 246-371 are necessary to bundle actin filaments.<ref name = "Field_1995" /> The ability of anillin to bind to and bundle actin together is conserved through many species. It is hypothesized that by regulating actin bundling, anillin increases the efficiency of actomyosin contractility during cell division. Both anillin and F-actin are found in contractile structures. They are recruited independently to the contractile ring, but F-actin increases the efficiency of anillin targeting.<ref name = "Piekny_2010" /> Anillin may also be involved in promoting the polymerization of F-actin by stabilizing formin mDia2 in an active form.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Watanabe S, Okawa K, Miki T, Sakamoto S, Morinaga T, Segawa K, Arakawa T, Kinoshita M, Ishizaki T, Narumiya S | title = Rho and anillin-dependent control of mDia2 localization and function in cytokinesis | journal = Molecular Biology of the Cell | volume = 21 | issue = 18 | pages = 3193–204 | date = September 2010 | pmid = 20660154 | pmc = 2938385 | doi = 10.1091/mbc.E10-04-0324 }}</ref>

===Myosin=== Anillin interacts directly with non-muscle myosin II and interacts indirectly with myosin via F-actin. Residues 142-254 (near the N-terminus) are essential for anillin binding myosin in ''Xenopus''. The interaction of anillin and myosin is also dependent on phosphorylation of the myosin light chain.<ref name = "Straight_2005">{{cite journal | vauthors = Straight AF, Field CM, Mitchison TJ | title = Anillin binds nonmuscle myosin II and regulates the contractile ring | journal = Molecular Biology of the Cell | volume = 16 | issue = 1 | pages = 193–201 | date = January 2005 | pmid = 15496454 | pmc = 539163 | doi = 10.1091/mbc.E04-08-0758 }}</ref> The interaction of myosin and anillin does not seem to serve in recruitment, but rather organization of myosin. In ''Drosophila'', anillin is necessary to organize myosin into rings in the cellularization front.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Field CM, Coughlin M, Doberstein S, Marty T, Sullivan W | title = Characterization of anillin mutants reveals essential roles in septin localization and plasma membrane integrity | journal = Development | volume = 132 | issue = 12 | pages = 2849–60 | date = June 2005 | pmid = 15930114 | doi = 10.1242/dev.01843 | doi-access = free }}</ref> Depletion of anillin in ''Drosophila'' and humans leads to changes in the spatial and temporal stability of myosin during cytokinesis.<ref name = "Goldbach_2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Goldbach P, Wong R, Beise N, Sarpal R, Trimble WS, Brill JA | title = Stabilization of the actomyosin ring enables spermatocyte cytokinesis in Drosophila | journal = Molecular Biology of the Cell | volume = 21 | issue = 9 | pages = 1482–93 | date = May 2010 | pmid = 20237160 | pmc = 2861608 | doi = 10.1091/mbc.E09-08-0714 }}</ref> In C. elegans, ANI-1 organizes myosin into foci during cytokinesis and establishment of polarity, whereas, ANI-2 is a requirement for the maintenance of myosin-rich contractile lining of oogenic gonads.<ref name = "Maddox_2005" />

===Septins=== Septin localization during cytokinesis and cellularization is dependent on its association with anillin.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Versele M, Thorner J | title = Some assembly required: yeast septins provide the instruction manual | journal = Trends in Cell Biology | volume = 15 | issue = 8 | pages = 414–24 | date = August 2005 | pmid = 16009555 | pmc = 1761124 | doi = 10.1016/j.tcb.2005.06.007 }}</ref> The direct interaction between anillin and septins was first shown by the interaction seen between ''Xenopus'' anillin and a minimal reconstituted heterooligomer of human septins 2, 6, and 7.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kinoshita M, Field CM, Coughlin ML, Straight AF, Mitchison TJ | title = Self- and actin-templated assembly of Mammalian septins | journal = Developmental Cell | volume = 3 | issue = 6 | pages = 791–802 | date = December 2002 | pmid = 12479805 | doi = 10.1016/S1534-5807(02)00366-0 | doi-access = free }}</ref> The ability of anillin to bind to septins is dependent on the C-terminal domain, which contains a terminal PH domain and an upstream sequence known as the “Anillin Homology” (AH) domain.<ref name = "Oegema_2000" />

===Rho=== The AH domain of human anillin is essential for its interaction with [[RhoA]]. Depletion of RhoA halts contractile ring assembly and ingression, whereas, anillin depletion leads to a less severe phenotype when the contractile ring forms and ingresses partially. Depletion of anillin in Drosophila spermatocytes greatly reduces the localization of Rho and F-actin to equatorial regions.<ref name = "Goldbach_2010" />

===Ect2=== Anillin interacts with [[ECT2|Ect2]], further supporting the idea that anillin stabilizes RhoA localization since Ect2 is an activator of RhoA. Independent of RhoA, the interaction between anillin and Ect2 occurs. This interaction is essential of the [[guanine nucleotide exchange factor|GEF]] activity of Ect2 and requires the AH domain of anillin and the PH domain of Ect2.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Solski PA, Wilder RS, Rossman KL, Sondek J, Cox AD, Campbell SL, Der CJ | title = Requirement for C-terminal sequences in regulation of Ect2 guanine nucleotide exchange specificity and transformation | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 279 | issue = 24 | pages = 25226–33 | date = June 2004 | pmid = 15073184 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M313792200 | doi-access = free }}</ref>

===Cyk-4=== ''Drosophila'' anillin interacts with Cyk-4, a central spindle protein, indicating that anillin may have a role in determining the division plane during cytokinesis.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Glotzer M | title = The 3Ms of central spindle assembly: microtubules, motors and MAPs | journal = Nature Reviews. Molecular Cell Biology | volume = 10 | issue = 1 | pages = 9–20 | date = January 2009 | pmid = 19197328 | pmc = 2789570 | doi = 10.1038/nrm2609 }}</ref> In anillin-depleted larval cells, the central spindle does not extend to the cortex.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gregory SL, Ebrahimi S, Milverton J, Jones WM, Bejsovec A, Saint R | title = Cell division requires a direct link between microtubule-bound RacGAP and Anillin in the contractile ring | journal = Current Biology | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | pages = 25–9 | date = January 2008 | pmid = 18158242 | doi = 10.1016/j.cub.2007.11.050 | s2cid = 17517089 | doi-access = free | bibcode = 2008CBio...18...25G }}</ref> Human anillin-depleted cells show improperly positioned and distorted central spindles.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Zhao WM, Fang G | title = Anillin is a substrate of anaphase-promoting complex/cyclosome (APC/C) that controls spatial contractility of myosin during late cytokinesis | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 280 | issue = 39 | pages = 33516–24 | date = September 2005 | pmid = 16040610 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M504657200 | doi-access = free }}</ref>

===Microtubules=== Anillin was first isolated from ''Drosophila'' by harnessing its interactions with both F-actin and microtubules.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Sisson JC, Field C, Ventura R, Royou A, Sullivan W | title = Lava lamp, a novel peripheral golgi protein, is required for Drosophila melanogaster cellularization | journal = The Journal of Cell Biology | volume = 151 | issue = 4 | pages = 905–18 | date = November 2000 | pmid = 11076973 | pmc = 2169433 | doi = 10.1083/jcb.151.4.905 | doi-access = free }}</ref> Furthermore, anillin-rich structures that form after Latrunculin A treatment of ''Drosophila'' cells localize to the plus-ends of microtubules.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hickson GR, O'Farrell PH | title = Rho-dependent control of anillin behavior during cytokinesis | journal = The Journal of Cell Biology | volume = 180 | issue = 2 | pages = 285–94 | date = January 2008 | pmid = 18209105 | pmc = 2213597 | doi = 10.1083/jcb.200709005 | doi-access = free }}</ref> The interaction between anillin and microtubules suggest that anillin may serve as a signaling factor to relay the position of the mitotic spindle to the cortex to ensure appropriate contractile ring formation during cytokinesis.<ref name = "Piekny_2010" />

Amino acids 258-340 are sufficient and necessary for F-actin binding in Drosophila, but amino acids 246-371 are necessary to bundle actin filaments.<ref name = "Field_1995" /> The ability of anillin to bind to and bundle actin together is conserved through many species. It is hypothesized that by regulating actin bundling, anillin increases the efficiency of actomyosin contractility during cell division. Both anillin and F-actin are found in contractile structures. They are recruited independently to the contractile ring, but F-actin increases the efficiency of anillin targeting.<ref name = "Piekny_2010" /> Anillin may also be involved in promoting the polymerization of F-actin by stabilizing formin mDia2 in an active form.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Watanabe S, Okawa K, Miki T, Sakamoto S, Morinaga T, Segawa K, Arakawa T, Kinoshita M, Ishizaki T, Narumiya S | title = Rho and anillin-dependent control of mDia2 localization and function in cytokinesis | journal = Molecular Biology of the Cell | volume = 21 | issue = 18 | pages = 3193–204 | date = September 2010 | pmid = 20660154 | pmc = 2938385 | doi = 10.1091/mbc.E10-04-0324 }}</ref>

title: Myosin
content: Anillin interacts directly with non-muscle myosin II and interacts indirectly with myosin via F-actin. Residues 142-254 (near the N-terminus) are essential for anillin binding myosin in ''Xenopus''. The interaction of anillin and myosin is also dependent on phosphorylation of the myosin light chain.<ref name = "Straight_2005">{{cite journal | vauthors = Straight AF, Field CM, Mitchison TJ | title = Anillin binds nonmuscle myosin II and regulates the contractile ring | journal = Molecular Biology of the Cell | volume = 16 | issue = 1 | pages = 193–201 | date = January 2005 | pmid = 15496454 | pmc = 539163 | doi = 10.1091/mbc.E04-08-0758 }}</ref> The interaction of myosin and anillin does not seem to serve in recruitment, but rather organization of myosin. In ''Drosophila'', anillin is necessary to organize myosin into rings in the cellularization front.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Field CM, Coughlin M, Doberstein S, Marty T, Sullivan W | title = Characterization of anillin mutants reveals essential roles in septin localization and plasma membrane integrity | journal = Development | volume = 132 | issue = 12 | pages = 2849–60 | date = June 2005 | pmid = 15930114 | doi = 10.1242/dev.01843 | doi-access = free }}</ref> Depletion of anillin in ''Drosophila'' and humans leads to changes in the spatial and temporal stability of myosin during cytokinesis.<ref name = "Goldbach_2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Goldbach P, Wong R, Beise N, Sarpal R, Trimble WS, Brill JA | title = Stabilization of the actomyosin ring enables spermatocyte cytokinesis in Drosophila | journal = Molecular Biology of the Cell | volume = 21 | issue = 9 | pages = 1482–93 | date = May 2010 | pmid = 20237160 | pmc = 2861608 | doi = 10.1091/mbc.E09-08-0714 }}</ref> In C. elegans, ANI-1 organizes myosin into foci during cytokinesis and establishment of polarity, whereas, ANI-2 is a requirement for the maintenance of myosin-rich contractile lining of oogenic gonads.<ref name = "Maddox_2005" />

title: Septins
content: Septin localization during cytokinesis and cellularization is dependent on its association with anillin.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Versele M, Thorner J | title = Some assembly required: yeast septins provide the instruction manual | journal = Trends in Cell Biology | volume = 15 | issue = 8 | pages = 414–24 | date = August 2005 | pmid = 16009555 | pmc = 1761124 | doi = 10.1016/j.tcb.2005.06.007 }}</ref> The direct interaction between anillin and septins was first shown by the interaction seen between ''Xenopus'' anillin and a minimal reconstituted heterooligomer of human septins 2, 6, and 7.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kinoshita M, Field CM, Coughlin ML, Straight AF, Mitchison TJ | title = Self- and actin-templated assembly of Mammalian septins | journal = Developmental Cell | volume = 3 | issue = 6 | pages = 791–802 | date = December 2002 | pmid = 12479805 | doi = 10.1016/S1534-5807(02)00366-0 | doi-access = free }}</ref> The ability of anillin to bind to septins is dependent on the C-terminal domain, which contains a terminal PH domain and an upstream sequence known as the “Anillin Homology” (AH) domain.<ref name = "Oegema_2000" />

title: Rho
content: The AH domain of human anillin is essential for its interaction with [[RhoA]]. Depletion of RhoA halts contractile ring assembly and ingression, whereas, anillin depletion leads to a less severe phenotype when the contractile ring forms and ingresses partially. Depletion of anillin in Drosophila spermatocytes greatly reduces the localization of Rho and F-actin to equatorial regions.<ref name = "Goldbach_2010" />

title: Ect2
content: Anillin interacts with [[ECT2|Ect2]], further supporting the idea that anillin stabilizes RhoA localization since Ect2 is an activator of RhoA. Independent of RhoA, the interaction between anillin and Ect2 occurs. This interaction is essential of the [[guanine nucleotide exchange factor|GEF]] activity of Ect2 and requires the AH domain of anillin and the PH domain of Ect2.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Solski PA, Wilder RS, Rossman KL, Sondek J, Cox AD, Campbell SL, Der CJ | title = Requirement for C-terminal sequences in regulation of Ect2 guanine nucleotide exchange specificity and transformation | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 279 | issue = 24 | pages = 25226–33 | date = June 2004 | pmid = 15073184 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M313792200 | doi-access = free }}</ref>

title: Cyk-4
content: ''Drosophila'' anillin interacts with Cyk-4, a central spindle protein, indicating that anillin may have a role in determining the division plane during cytokinesis.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Glotzer M | title = The 3Ms of central spindle assembly: microtubules, motors and MAPs | journal = Nature Reviews. Molecular Cell Biology | volume = 10 | issue = 1 | pages = 9–20 | date = January 2009 | pmid = 19197328 | pmc = 2789570 | doi = 10.1038/nrm2609 }}</ref> In anillin-depleted larval cells, the central spindle does not extend to the cortex.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gregory SL, Ebrahimi S, Milverton J, Jones WM, Bejsovec A, Saint R | title = Cell division requires a direct link between microtubule-bound RacGAP and Anillin in the contractile ring | journal = Current Biology | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | pages = 25–9 | date = January 2008 | pmid = 18158242 | doi = 10.1016/j.cub.2007.11.050 | s2cid = 17517089 | doi-access = free | bibcode = 2008CBio...18...25G }}</ref> Human anillin-depleted cells show improperly positioned and distorted central spindles.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Zhao WM, Fang G | title = Anillin is a substrate of anaphase-promoting complex/cyclosome (APC/C) that controls spatial contractility of myosin during late cytokinesis | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 280 | issue = 39 | pages = 33516–24 | date = September 2005 | pmid = 16040610 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M504657200 | doi-access = free }}</ref>

title: Microtubules
content: Anillin was first isolated from ''Drosophila'' by harnessing its interactions with both F-actin and microtubules.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Sisson JC, Field C, Ventura R, Royou A, Sullivan W | title = Lava lamp, a novel peripheral golgi protein, is required for Drosophila melanogaster cellularization | journal = The Journal of Cell Biology | volume = 151 | issue = 4 | pages = 905–18 | date = November 2000 | pmid = 11076973 | pmc = 2169433 | doi = 10.1083/jcb.151.4.905 | doi-access = free }}</ref> Furthermore, anillin-rich structures that form after Latrunculin A treatment of ''Drosophila'' cells localize to the plus-ends of microtubules.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hickson GR, O'Farrell PH | title = Rho-dependent control of anillin behavior during cytokinesis | journal = The Journal of Cell Biology | volume = 180 | issue = 2 | pages = 285–94 | date = January 2008 | pmid = 18209105 | pmc = 2213597 | doi = 10.1083/jcb.200709005 | doi-access = free }}</ref> The interaction between anillin and microtubules suggest that anillin may serve as a signaling factor to relay the position of the mitotic spindle to the cortex to ensure appropriate contractile ring formation during cytokinesis.<ref name = "Piekny_2010" />

title: Regulation
content:
Anillins in metazoans are heavily phosphorylated; however, the kinases responsible for the phosphorylation are unknown at the present time. In humans and ''Drosophila'', anillins are recruited to the equatorial cortex in a RhoA-dependent manner. This recruitment is independent of other cytoskeletal Rho targets such as myosin, F-actin, and Rho-kinase. It has been observed that anillin proteolysis is triggered after mitotic exit by the [[Anaphase Promoting Complex]] (APC).

Most anillins can be sequestered to the nucleus during [[interphase]], but there are exceptions – ''Drosophila'' anilins in the early embryo, C. elegans ANI-1 in early embryos, ''C. elegans'' ANI-2 in oogenic gonads, and Mid2p in fission yeast. These anillins that are not sequestered during interphase suggest that anillins may also regulate cytoskeletal dynamics outside the contractile ring during cytokinesis.<ref name = "Zhang_2010" />

title: Role in Diseases
content: Anillin is critical for cell division and therefore development and homeostasis in metazoans. In recent years, the expression levels of anillin have been shown to correlate to the metastatic potential of human tumours. In colorectal cancer, expression levels of anillin are higher in tumours and when anillin was over-expressed in HT29 cells, a classical [[colorectal cancer]] cell line, the cells showed faster replication kinetics due to the lengthening of G2/M phase. Increasing the expression of anillin also led to further invasiveness and migration of numerous colorectal cancer cell lines. The hypothesis from such observations is that anillin promotes EMT and [[cell migration]] through cytoskeletal remodeling, leading to enhanced proliferation, invasion, and mobility of tumour cells.<ref>{{cite conference | vauthors = Chuang HY, Ou YH | title = Overexpression of anillin in colorectal cancer promoter the cell proliferation, cell mobility and cell invasion. | conference = Proceedings of the 105th Annual Meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research | location = San Diego, CA. | date = 2014 }}</ref><ref name="pmid27062703">{{cite journal | vauthors = Wang G, Shen W, Cui L, Chen W, Hu X, Fu J | title = Overexpression of Anillin (ANLN) is correlated with colorectal cancer progression and poor prognosis | journal = Cancer Biomarkers | volume = 16 | issue = 3 | pages = 459–65 | date = 2016 | pmid = 27062703 | doi = 10.3233/CBM-160585 }}</ref>
